Comment: e4 is a strong sensible opening which immediately places a pawn in the center and opens up line for the queen and bishop.
A good response to e4, for the same reasons as white.
Nf3, a strong move that places pressure on the black pawn at e5.
d6 is not the best move to make, to a cautious player it may be worth playing but d6 creates a cramped position for black.
Bc4, this places whites bishop on a strong square to extend control.
f6, a weak move as now three pawns have been moved without a single piece having developed. f6 also takes away the knights strong developing square.
Nc3, now all of the knights for white are developed as well as a bishop, black has just three pawns.
Black expects the knight to be pinned to the queen.
The beginning of Legall's mate. Surprise! WHat is this white has made a blunder and has lost his queen to the black bishop and it is only move 5.
Black took the bait. Checkmate in two moves.
Notice the white knight on e5 protects the bishop and stops the king from moving to d7.
The knight from c3 seals the deal. A tip to avoid this situation if you are black is to avoid taking the queen.
